narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Understandings of important Air Force competencies
Better understanding of AF communication, bullet writing, leadership and communication methods
understanding of leadership fundamentals, techniques, styles and exposure to AF military structures
This course was a good look into the life of an Air Force officer and how to be successful in the Air Force.
Better understanding of real AF life
I learned how to practice communication and how to be a better leader.
Learned about elements of being an officer in the USAF, such as our m.o., relationship to the enlisted core, and cultural considerations.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It basically followed the prescribed Air Force ROTC curriculum, so there's not much else I could ask for

Strength: great class discussions! 
Weakness: a lot of powerpoint presentations could have been converted into class discussion.

Strengths:
structured syllabus with clear expectations, assignment details, and class format
very manageable workload
working flexibility with understanding of Covid circumstances

The material of this course was relevant and the discussions were engaging and very applicable to our future careers. However, the standards for grading were often very unclear. More clarity on the grading scale for reflection papers and class participation would have been helpful.
Lt Col Tseng going off slide and making it personal was nice. I think I got more out of her personal advice and anecdotes than a lot of the official slides.
I liked the discussion-focused format of the class.

While each lesson had an associated powerpoint, the actual lectures turned were more discussion-based, for better and worse. On one hand, it was easier to understand in real time the importance of each lesson, but on the other, it made it very difficult to stay organized and track what we were learning with notes.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think slightly shorter lectures than the 1.5 hours on monday might be a little bit better for the virtual format.

Success: Group projects went well despite online format 
Improvement: More discussion in breakout rooms would increase engagement.
Taking breaks during lectures, creating group assignments, and utilizing the online presentation format all helped, and most especially being flexible with deadlines and assignments

The course was engaging despite the virtual platform, although some clarity on participation procedures (i.e. hand raising vs. speaking out) would have been helpful, especially near the end of the semester.
For most classes, we went through a powerpoint and had discussions based on the information on the slides.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you want to do AFROTC you have to
Yes, but only to AFROTC cadets.
definitely recommend this course!
Yes
Yes, I learned a lot.
